title: Abbreviations
description: Learn the proper use of abbreviations in Canadian government writing

content.text: Abbreviations save space and time in writing, but they must be used carefully to maintain clarity. This chapter covers Canadian government standards for creating and using abbreviations effectively.

keyPrinciple.title: Key Principle
keyPrinciple.content: Use abbreviations sparingly in formal writing. When in doubt, spell it out completely.

warningBox.title: When to Use Abbreviations
items: In technical documents where space is limited
For widely recognized terms (e.g., etc., i.e., e.g.)
For units of measurement in scientific contexts
In tables, charts, and reference lists
When the abbreviation is more familiar than the full form

content.text: Follow these fundamental principles when using abbreviations:
principles: Always define an abbreviation on first use, unless it is extremely well known
Be consistent—once you choose an abbreviation, use it throughout the document
Consider your audience when deciding whether to abbreviate
Avoid using too many abbreviations in a single document

examples.text: The Canadian Broadcasting Corporation (CBC) announced new programming. The CBC will focus on...
The CBC announced new programming. (Without first defining it)

content.text: Generally, do not begin a sentence with an abbreviation. If you must, spell out the word or restructure the sentence.

examples.text: Dr. Smith will speak at the conference.
Doctor Smith will speak at the conference.
The conference will feature Dr. Smith as a speaker.

content.note: Exceptions exist for titles that are always abbreviated (Mr., Mrs., Dr.) when restructuring would be awkward.

content.text: The use of periods in abbreviations follows specific rules:

rules.rule: Use periods after abbreviations for single words
Use periods after each abbreviated word in multi-word terms
Use periods after initials in personal names

keyPrinciple.title: Spacing Rule
keyPrinciple.content: Include a space between initials and following names, but not between initials themselves when they form an acronym.

content.text: Form plurals of abbreviations according to these guidelines:

rules.rule: Use apostrophe + s for numerical aircraft names ending in a single letter
Use apostrophe + s when confusion might arise
Add apostrophe + s for abbreviations with multiple periods

content.note: SI/metric symbols maintain the same form for both singular and plural and are written without periods, except at the end of a sentence.

content.text: Use the following abbreviations for non-military titles preceding or following personal names:

keyPrinciple.title: Usage of Ms.
keyPrinciple.content: Use Ms. when referring to a woman unless a preference for Mrs. has been indicated. Although not an abbreviation, Ms. is written with a period, by analogy with Mr. and Mrs. Note that Miss is not an abbreviation and does not take a period.

warningBox.title: Important Rule
warningBox.content: Do not use Mr., Mrs., Ms., Dr. or Esq. with any other abbreviated title or with an abbreviation for an academic degree.

examples.text: Dr. John Smith, Ph.D.
Dr. John Smith or John Smith, Ph.D.
Mr. William Jones, Esq.
Mr. William Jones or William Jones, Esq.

content.text: Military ranks and titles follow specific abbreviation conventions:
content.note: In formal military documents, consult the appropriate military style guide for complete lists and usage rules.

content.text: Abbreviate geographical terms according to these guidelines:
rules: Generally spell out names of countries, provinces, and territories in text
Abbreviate in addresses, lists, and when space is limited
Use standard postal abbreviations for provinces and territories

keyPrinciple.title: In Formal Text
keyPrinciple.content: Spell out province and territory names in formal documents and running text. Use abbreviations primarily in addresses and tables.

content.text: Common Latin abbreviations used in English writing:

abbreviations.usage: Use in parenthetical material; spell out 'for example' in main text
Use in parenthetical material; spell out 'that is' in main text
Acceptable in all contexts, but avoid overuse
Used in citations with multiple authors

warningBox.title: Avoid Overuse
warningBox.content: In formal writing, prefer English equivalents. Reserve Latin abbreviations for parenthetical material and scholarly contexts.

content.text: Abbreviate time and date expressions as follows:
dateAbbreviations: Jan., Feb., Mar., Apr., May, June, July, Aug., Sept., Oct., Nov., Dec.
Mon., Tues., Wed., Thurs., Fri., Sat., Sun.

keyPrinciple.title: In Formal Writing
keyPrinciple.content: Spell out months and days of the week in formal text. Use abbreviations in tables, lists, and when space is constrained.

examples.text: The meeting is scheduled for 2:00 p.m. on Tuesday, March 15.
Meeting: 2:00 p.m., Tues., Mar. 15 (in a calendar or schedule)

content.text: Guidelines for abbreviating business and organization names:
rules: Use the organization's preferred abbreviation or acronym
Define acronyms on first use unless extremely well known
Respect the organization's capitalization and spacing preferences

examples.text: The Canadian Broadcasting Corporation (CBC) will air the documentary. CBC representatives confirmed...
Smith & Sons Ltd. announced new products.

keyPrinciple.title: Placement
keyPrinciple.content: Academic degrees follow the person's name and are set off by commas. Do not use a title (Dr., Mr., etc.) with a degree.

examples.text: Jane Smith, Ph.D., will lead the research.
Dr. Jane Smith will lead the research.
Dr. Jane Smith, Ph.D., will lead the research.

keyPrinciple.title: Critical Rules for SI Symbols
keyPrinciple.content: SI symbols are not abbreviations. They are never followed by periods (except at the end of a sentence) and never take a plural 's'.

examples.text: The box measures 5 cm by 10 cm.
Add 250 mL of water.
The box measures 5 cms. by 10 cms.

content.text: Common symbols and when to use them:

symbols.name: Ampersand
symbols.usage: Use only in official business names and in certain established phrases. Otherwise, spell out 'and'.

symbols.name: Percent
symbols.usage: Acceptable in technical and statistical contexts. In formal writing, spell out 'percent' after the number.

symbols.name: Dollar sign
symbols.usage: Place before the number with no space: $50, $1,000

symbols.name: Number sign
symbols.usage: Avoid in formal writing. Use 'No.' or spell out 'number'.

symbols.name: At sign
symbols.usage: Acceptable in email addresses and informal contexts only.

examples.text: The budget increased by 15 percent (or 15% in technical writing).
AT&T Corp. (official business name)
The research & development team met yesterday.

content.text: Abbreviating names of government departments and agencies:
rules: Use full name on first reference
Capitalize all letters in most federal abbreviations

examples.text: The Department of National Defence (DND) announced new policies. DND will implement...
Statistics Canada (StatCan) released new data.
The Canada Revenue Agency (CRA) updated its guidelines.

content.note: Some departments have official short forms that may differ from strict abbreviations. Use the department's preferred form.

content.text: Understanding the difference and proper usage:

definitions.definition: An abbreviation pronounced as a word (e.g., NATO, radar, scuba)
An abbreviation pronounced letter by letter (e.g., FBI, CBC, HTML)

capitalizationRules: Acronyms of five letters or fewer: usually all capitals (NATO, RCMP)
Acronyms of six letters or more: may be written with initial capital only (Unicef, Nato) when well established
Initialisms: always all capitals (CBC, UN, MP)

keyPrinciple.title: First Use Rule
keyPrinciple.content: Always provide the full term on first use, followed by the acronym/initialism in parentheses, unless the abbreviation is more familiar than the full form.

exceptions: Very well-known acronyms (NATO, UN, FBI) may not need definition
Common technology terms (DVD, USB, CD) are often used without definition

examples.text: The North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO) held a summit. NATO members agreed...
Insert the USB drive. (No definition needed - universally known)

errors.incorrect: The MP's voted on the bill.
errors.correct: The MPs voted on the bill.
errors.explanation: Only use apostrophes for possessives, not plurals

errors.incorrect: The report includes data from N.A.T.O. and NATO.
errors.correct: The report includes data from NATO.

errors.incorrect: The dept. rep. met w/ the govt. off. re: the proj.
errors.correct: The department representative met with the government official regarding the project.

errors.explanation: SI symbols never take periods except at sentence end
Spell out abbreviations at the start of sentences

warningBox.title: Remember
warningBox.content: When in doubt about an abbreviation, spell it out. Clarity should always take precedence over brevity.
